items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are falling at the Clay Coton river gauge after persistent heavy rainfall yesterday 16/03/2022. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today, 17/03/2022. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to continue falling throughout today 17/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 17/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on Thursday the 17th March 2022 at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of yesterday’s heavy rainfall. We expect the River Avon to remain high for the next coming days; its possible there will be some flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   

The weather forecast for the rest of the week looks positive with no major rainfall totals forecast. We will continue to closely monitoring the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated this evening, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to begin gradually falling at approximately 17:00 this evening, 17/03/22, but remain high overnight tonight and into tomorrow, 18/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thame as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land possible today (17/3/22) especially around Thame Bridge and Stadhampton. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message this evening, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

River levels have risen at the Southam river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 17/03/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to rise until later this morning, 17/03/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:45 on 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and its tributaries rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected and we expect to remove this flood alert tomorrow.  However, river levels will remain high over the next 24 hours.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the North Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and its tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the morning of Thursday 17th March onwards. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.message:
River levels have risen at the Walton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 17/03/22.     
No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Brackley river gauge after yesterday’s rainfall. 

Consequently, flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible over Thursday night, 17/03/2022.
  
We expect flooding to affect the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.

Drier, brighter conditions are forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to continue to fall during this time.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated on Friday morning, 18/03/2022.

River levels are falling but remain high at the Cappenham river gauge after yesterday’s rainfall. 

Consequently, flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible over Thursday night, 17/03/2022.
  
We expect flooding to affect River Tove from Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook   

Drier, brighter conditions are forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to continue to fall during this time. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated on Friday morning, 18/03/2022.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Wimpole river gauge as a result of yesterday’s rainfall. 

Consequently, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible over the course of today, 17/03/2022.  
We expect flooding to affect the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield.   
  
Drier, brighter conditions are forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high during the course of today and into this evening.

We will continue to monitor the situation.   

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/03/2022.

River levels are falling at the Temple Mill river gauge after persistent heavy rainfall yesterday 16/03/2022. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today, 17/03/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to continue falling throughout today 17/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 17/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high after yesterday's rain in the Gillingham Le Neubourg Way area. Consequently, their is still  a risk of localised flooding. We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton.  River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the River Welland catchment. This means that the Welland tributaries rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected.  However, whilst most river levels are falling, Eye Brook is still rising and will remain high over the next few days.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor watercourses of the South Forty Foot Drain
items.message: Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the minor watercourses of South Forty Foot Drain catchment area. This means that the rivers rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected, however, some river levels will remain high. We expect to remove this flood alert in the next 48 hours. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sence from Temple Mill to Sheepy Magna

items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater is now falling. As high pressure builds, the weather is now mostly dry for the next five days. This will allow the river plenty of chance to recover, returning to a more normal level by tomorrow (18/03/2022). We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Ise and Alledge Brook catchment area. This means that the River Ise and Alledge Brook are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to these rivers from the morning of Thursday, 17th March onwards. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Nene catchment. This means that the River Nene and its tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to these rivers from this morning, Thursday, 17th March onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Cole downstream of Swindon as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and land is possible today (17/3/22), especially in the Westmill Bridge area. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message this evening, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

River levels have risen at the Hammoon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday afternoon. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from now until 10:00 tomorrow, Friday the 17/03/22.  We expect flooding to affect West Street, Shorts Lane, Barnack Walk, Market Place, Sheep Market Hill, East Street, Nightingale Court, Damory Street, River Mews and Langton Road in Blandford   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 12:00 on 17/03/22
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.
